Some further consideratons in a more structure form
 - scenario 1: The P5 reach an agreement by Oct 1 or so, Georgieva is nominated and wins. Probability: 20%
 - scenario 2: no agreement by Oct 1.  In the first Oct poll, every candidate is vetoed or does not collect 9 approvals. Negotiations continue, Georgieva is nominated later and wins (15%)
 - Scenario 3: one of P5 is adamant against Georgieva, she does not get nominated, a man from the current candidates wins (60%) 
 - Scenario 4: Georgieva is nominated after all, but does not win (5%).

This is getting complicated. The Bulgarian government will support Bokova until the poll on Sep 26, and afterwards if she is first or second at that poll. If she is not (as it is very likely), they "will see". This looks like leaving the door open without committing one way or the other. But the important issue is whether Georgieva will agree to be nominated. My guess is that she will agree only if it's clear that she will be supported by the P5. So between now and October, the P5 will have to bargain on the distribution of top UN posts. If the Russians and the Chinese get what they want (various UN posts, or other stuff), then Georgieva will be nominated and will likely win. If not, she won't be nominated and the likely winner is a man.  Hard to predict whether such an agreement can be reached. The Russians and the US are working together in Syria now, but this may unravel quickly.  The West can also try to agree with China - where the relations are a tad less adversarial - and isolate Russia. But then Georgieva won't probably be nominated.

UN-watchers say there is almost a consensus that Mr Ban’s successor should be an eastern European woman—because no one satisfying either criterion has ever been chosen. Bulgaria has nominated Irina Bokova, the head of UNESCO, the UN’s cultural arm. But early in her career she was a loyal Muscovite Communist, so America may block her. If Bulgaria then names Kristalina Georgieva, the European Union’s budget commissioner, who may also fancy a shot, the Russians may block her because of the sanctions imposed by the EU on Russia over its actions in Ukraine.

The idea has taken hold that a woman should get the job, because none has done it before; and that she should be from eastern Europe, because that part of the world has never had the honour.
But if one of them succeeds it should be because of her ability, rather than her gender or her home country. Whoever is chosen will have to tackle grave problems. The UN is bloated, seemingly unaccountable, dogged by bureaucracy and tangled in institutional rivalries.
The outgoing secretary-general, Ban Ki-moon, whose term finishes at the end of this year, is widely regarded as a failure in both administration and governance.
Whoever succeeds him will find the job hard enough. A Bulgarian front-runner, Irina Bokova, was a diplomat for the former communist regime; America may object. If she bows out another Bulgarian, Kristalina Georgieva, the EU’s respected budget boss, would be better.
